Today is the #StateOpening of Parliament.   

Itâ€™s a ceremonial occasion and a key part of Parliamentâ€™s business year. The government presents its agenda for the year ahead in The Queenâ€™s Speech. https://t.co/SCW4mWvYSe

This year's State Opening of Parliament will be added to this list of extraordinary ceremonies, and you can watch with us on Tuesday.

For now, hear more about unusual State Openings on the @ukhouseoflords podcast: https://t.co/TCVPl7wkZR

The Monarch is one of the three parts of Parliament, and central to State Opening. Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II has opened Parliament personally all but two times during her reign.

These were in 1959 and 1963, when she was pregnant with HRH Prince Andrew and HRH Prince Edward.

Day dress was also worn in 2017 and 2019 following short-notice elections. Look back to images from those days with the @UKHouseofLords:

https://t.co/o3REnyFEu4

https://t.co/pn5GXVIYaH https://t.co/3NkPicZWmM

Some State Openings have also had reduced ceremonial elements when there has been little notice due to snap elections.

For this reason in March 1974, the Queen interrupted a foreign tour at short notice to open Parliament in person, and wore day dress to Parliament.

While the @UKHouseofLords is usually a place of business, State Opening is one of the few times we see the House and the monarch in full pageantry.

However, during the First and Second World Wars ceremony was pushed aside, with King George VI in uniform of Admiral of the Fleet.

So when did State Opening begin?

Some of the traditions surrounding the State Opening and the delivery of a speech by the monarch can be traced back to at least the 16th century.

However, the modern ceremony dates from the opening of the new Palace of Westminster in 1852.

Next Tuesday a new Parliamentary session will start after the State Opening of Parliament.

But next week's ceremony will be COVID-secure and unlike any other. Let's look back to other times State Opening didn't look like State Opening. https://t.co/We4YbYtHPu

The next time the @UKHouseofLords and @HouseofCommons will sit will be for the State Opening of Parliament on 11 May. 

State Opening is when the Monarch formally starts the next session, and sets out the Government's priorities for the year ahead in the Queen's Speech.

Following a ceremony in the House of Lords, UK Parliament has now prorogued.

What is prorogation? It's the term for when Parliament's session ends. A session is normally around a year long, but there isn't a set length. https://t.co/ZJzfTE7TFf

As well as being the last day of the 2019-21 session, itâ€™s Lord Fowlerâ€™s last day as @LordSpeaker. 

After five years championing the work of the #HouseofLords, his focus now is on campaigning on HIV/AIDS and other issues from the backbenches.

Many thanks to the City of London change ringing society the Ancient Society of College Youths for their research on Great Tom: https://t.co/8g5f3PjMM9

As clockmaking matured, hour bells fell out of use and in 1698 Great Tom was given to St Margaret's, the church standing opposite Westminster Hall. The bell was later sold to @stpaulslondon where it currently resides.

Exactly when Great Tom was cast is unclear, but records suggest a fine levied on a 13th century chief justice was used to pay for a tower and a bell to be struck each hour, to remind judges at the nearby court of the offence.

Great Tom or Westminster Tom was the nickname given to the large bell in a clock tower at the north end of the Palace of Westminster. This was before the Palace burned in 1834 and was remade as the Gothic Revival building we know today.

In years past in Westminster, you may have heard from Tom before you heard from Ben. Who do we mean? 

Many people know the current bell at the top of the Elizabeth Tower as Big Ben. Ben's predecessor, though, was known as Great Tom. Read on as we ring the changes ğŸ‘‡ğŸ”” https://t.co/Z2ehgVIDDD

The census form gives the address as 'Found hiding in crypt of Westminster Hall' - and being the only one there, she was listed as the head of the household.

Other supporters looked to Parliament as a way to use the census to draw attention to their cause. 

Emily Wilding Davison hid in a cupboard in the Chapel of St Mary Undercroft in the House of Commons on census night 1911, in order to have herself enumerated within Westminster.

In 1911, after many years of campaigning, women were still being denied the right to vote. 

When the time came to fill out the census, some suffragettes supported a mass census boycott, shown in this badge by the Tax Resistance League and Women's Freedom League. https://t.co/aZS2d1zixH

Despite this adversity, it was a new dawn for women MPs, and today a contemporary light sculpture of this name stands above the entrance to St Stephen's Hall.

'New Dawn' by Mary Branson celebrates the campaign for women's votes, and the many individuals involved in the movement. https://t.co/RIkM4yhukS

From 1919, the new wave of women MPs necessitated infrastructure change. As well as toilets, a Lady Member's Room had to be provided.

However, the room assigned was poorly furnished and overcrowded, forcing MPs to sit on the floor to do paperwork and hold meetings in corridors.

Another tribute to women's fight for equality can be found beneath the Palace, on a broom cupboard in Parliament's chapel, St Mary Undercroft.

The night before the 1911 census, suffragette Emily Wilding Davison hid in this cupboard overnight to protest for women's right to vote. https://t.co/s4MKnoTeWG

Many people were interested in owning these important parts of history, and one grille was sent on permanent loan to the @MuseumofLondon.

But most of the grilles are placed around Central Lobby, where anyone can see them. View them on our virtual tour: https://t.co/hGAFHO373e

These grilles became a symbol of women's exclusion from Parliament, and a target for suffragette protests.

In 1917, after much debate, the grilles came down. https://t.co/RCaBBV0nJq

When the Palace of Westminster was rebuilt after the fire of 1834, a special "Ladies' Gallery" was added into the @HouseofCommons Chamber. 

The Gallery was covered by heavy metal grilles which made it hard to see or hear what was happening in debates. https://t.co/qcXbWFWE0q

Before 1834, women weren't allowed to watch debates in the @HouseofCommons - but many wanted to.

Some women watched debates from a ventilator shaft in the ceiling of the Chamber designed to let out heat and smoke. It was hot, cramped, and only available to well-connected women. https://t.co/bTAJTo7Lts

It's #WomensHistoryMonth, and this month we'll be talking about women who've made history in Parliament.

But today we're digging deeper, into the very bricks and mortar, to look at how the Palace of Westminster itself was shaped by women and the fight for equality.

â¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸â¬‡ï¸ https://t.co/wF6K9rJPbp

The Parliamentary Archives has images of the original Bill of Rights on its website. Follow the link to see the handwritten, hand-stitched vellum version: https://t.co/EWsEv3rqvk ğŸ“œ

The original document is still held by the Parliamentary Archives in our beautiful Victoria Tower. The manuscript is a unique piece of democratic history, and links todayâ€™s Parliament with its predecessors hundreds of years ago.
The Bill of Rights made clear that the monarch could not change the law or raise taxes without Parliament's agreement. It also stated that members of Parliament should be elected freely.
Parts of the Bill of Rights are still the law in the UK and several Commonwealth countries, and you can read it along with all current laws on the official https://t.co/I3zduMYBV4 website.

ğŸ‘‘ â€œ â€¦ execution of laws by regal authority without consent of Parliament is illegal â€¦â€

The Race Relations Acts were superseded by the Equality Act 2010, which created nine protected characteristics against which it is illegal to discriminate. These include someone's race, as well as other characteristics like disabilities, religion, or gender.

It was followed in 1968 by another Race Relations Act, which outlawed discrimination in employment, housing and advertising. In turn, this was followed by an act in 1976 which banned any practice that disadvantaged a particular racial group.

The Act set up the Race Relations Board, dealing with complaints of racial discrimination. The Board heard 327 complaints in its first year.

The 1965 Act was criticised for not addressing more areas where discrimination affected people, areas like employment and accommodation. https://t.co/d5mN4HfHWL

Those pushing for the law included West Indian cricketer Learie Constantine. Because he was Black, in 1943 Constantine was denied entry to a hotel. He took the hotel to court, winning a landmark High Court case. 

He later became the first Black peer in the @UKHouseofLords. https://t.co/94bleIoUEl

It was the first in a series of laws that sought to outlaw discrimination on racial grounds in Britain. It banned racial discrimination in public places and made the promotion of hatred on the grounds of â€˜colour, race, or ethnic or national origins' an offence.
The Race Relations Act 1965 came into force #OnThisDay in 1965. It had become a law exactly a month before on 8 November 1965. âœ”ï¸ https://t.co/AZ8g3k8aOQ

Astor's legacy is complex, and should be seen in context of her later views.

But both Markievicz and Astor made remarkable contributions to Parliamentary history, paving the way for other women. There's now a record number of women in the @houseofcommons and further still to go. https://t.co/HTWFOfSzXV

Fast forward a year.

It's 1919, and Nancy Astor is elected MP for Plymouth Sutton. She does take her seat, and for nearly two years she's the only woman MP.

Astor gets a cold reception from her fellow MPs - Winston Churchill later tells her that "we hoped to freeze you out". https://t.co/7dynsRcJeZ

Constance Markievicz is part of the Sinn FÃ©in party, whose policy is to abstain from taking their seats in Westminster.

So although Markievicz was elected an MP, she didn't take her seat.

It's all in the semantics. If we're talking about the first woman to be elected an MP, let us introduce Constance Markievicz - the MP for Dublin St Patrick's in 1918.

And it really used to be the law to remember the 5th of November.

In 1606, the Thanksgiving Act was passed. It required everyone in England to attend church for a public thanksgiving for the failure of the plot every 5th November until the law was repealed in 1859. https://t.co/PtGs7jBvGY

This kind of treason wasn't taken lightly in 1605. This is the Attainder of Guy Fawkes, which declares him guilty and in line for punishment without trial. It also strips him of any property and prevents him passing anything on via inheritance if sentenced to death, which he was. https://t.co/0cHqpY8daO

The Gunpowder Plot was also recorded in the official @houseofcommons journal. 

This marginal note in the Commons Journal records "36 barrels of gunpowder in the vault under the House, with a purpose to blow King and the whole Company, when they should there assemble". https://t.co/tfwwPFKFvs

The Gunpowder Plot - a failed attempt by a group of conspirators to assassinate the King in 1605 - is still remembered in UK Parliament today.

Before every State Opening of Parliament, the Yeoman of the Guard search the @ukhouseoflords cellars. Here they are in 1901 and 2016. https://t.co/U3LPAHxwK0

Remember, remember, the 5th of November... after all, it's the law. Or, it used to be, at least.

The grille had to be removed from the window to free the suffragettes from it. Unfortunately, it took 9 more years of campaigning to get the grilles removed for good.

Removal of the Ladiesâ€™ Gallery grille, 23 August 1917, Courtesy of In-House Services & Estates Archive https://t.co/OEf7aYXJ3Y

On the 28th October 1908, Murial Matters and Helen Fox chained themselves to the grille, shouting "We have been behind this insulting grille too long!" as Violet Tillard thrust a banner through the grille into the Commons Chamber.

In 1834, the Ladies' Gallery was created in the @ukhouseofcommons. It had windows covered with heavy metal grilles which made it hard to see or hear what was going on. These grilles became a symbol of women's exclusion from Parliament.

Campaigners and abolitionists like Olaudah Equiano changed the course of Parliamentary history. 

But so often this isn't about one law or a single win - it's consistent progress, which is why we continue to mark and celebrate #BlackHistoryMonth.
We know Equiano as someone whose voice changed the course of Parliamentary history - just as yours might by starting a petition, contacting a member or giving evidence to a committee.

Equiano played a key role in the passing of the Slave Trade Act of 1807, which ended British support for the slave trade.

Slavery itself was not outlawed until the Slavery Abolition Act of 1833, which made it illegal to purchase or own a slave in most of the British Empire.
Laws did change - though not until after Equiano's death in 1797, and it was still years until slavery in this form was outlawed completely.

His autobiography, 'The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano', detailed his difficult journey from slavery to freedom and becoming an educated man. This book changed many minds about slave trading laws, and fuelled the growing anti-slavery movement.

And this was one of Equiano's routes for political change. 

After living as a slave for many years, buying his freedom and moving to England, he began to speak directly to Parliament about the laws around the transatlantic slave trade.

He attended debates in the @houseofcommons and wrote to MPs to share his views. 

A letter he wrote to Lord Hawkesbury was read to a Parliamentary Committee as evidence against the slave trade - hear some of it here. https://t.co/61xqYqDynt

Throughout #BlackHistoryMonth we're highlighting some of the Black parliamentarians who are making history.

Itâ€™s also important to remember those who paved the way for modern society and democracy as we know it, such as writer and abolitionist Olaudah Equiano. https://t.co/rhQcmg729Y

The existing Speakerâ€™s Chair is made of black bean wood from North Queensland and the elaborate carving includes â€˜The gift of Australiaâ€™ in Gothic lettering.

The Canadian House of @OurCommons also have a replica of the Speakerâ€™s Chair in their Chamber. https://t.co/lonkvEKTDN

The chair was a gift to the British Parliament from Australia in 1950.

However, the Speakerâ€™s Chair in the @houseofcommons also has a lot of history. It is a replica of Augustus Puginâ€™s design for the Speakerâ€™s Chair from 1849, which was destroyed when the Commons Chamber was bombed in 1941. https://t.co/DbfEQ2IZnf

ğŸ’¬ "What is the most historically significant chair?" â“

The Sovereign's Throne is one of the most important items of furniture in the Palace of Westminster. It has been used by the monarch for the State Opening of Parliament since 1852. https://t.co/HQJsan5j9a

ğŸ’¬ "What is the oldest item in the collection?" â“

One of the oldest pieces is this silver tankard. The Latin inscription tells us it was probably a gift from John Warner, Bishop of Rochester, to Chaloner Chute, a lawyer, politician and Speaker of the @HouseofCommons (1654-9). https://t.co/ARdJAOLYqf

So, the Palace of Westminster was left to rebuild, and in 1870 Charles Barry and Augustus Pugin's Gothic vision of the Palace we know today was completed - 150 years ago.

And to this day, no more tally sticks are stored in the Houses of Parliament.

#Westminster150

And they do. By concentrating all their efforts on the wooden beams of Westminster Hall, and aided by a change in wind direction, this part of the Palace is saved. 

By 5am the fire is out - but most of the building is destroyed, including the @houseofcommons and @ukhouseoflords.

Inside the Palace of Westminster, it's less relaxed. Despite efforts of 12 fire engines, 64 firemen and hundreds of volunteers, the fire spreads.

The Chancellor of the Exchequer cries instructions to "Damn the House of Commons, let it blaze away!" but "Save, O save the Hall!"

Must be quite the picture. But remember, it's 1834 - no one has an iPhone to document events like this.

So before long, the river front is lined with artists, including Turner and Constable, sketching and painting the scene until the fire reaches its height at 11pm.

The light from the fire is so bright you can read the small print of a newspaper from Pedlar's Acre (where the London Eye stands today) as if it were daytime.

It can be seen by the King and Queen from Windsor, and from all the home counties.

6pm - fire! ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ğŸ”¥ 

The @ukhouseoflords is on fire and in no time at all, the rest of the Palace is ablaze. 

Staff are unable to get the fire under control, and at 6:30pm a huge fireball bursts through the ceiling, lighting up the sky and drawing crowds from all over London.

The morning of the 16th of October, two workmen arrive at the Palace to burn the sticks.

That afternoon, visitors notice heat and smoke seeping from the @UKHouseofLords floor. But the workmen finish, put out the furnace by 5pm, and the Palace is locked for the night.

It's 1834, and the Palace of Westminster looks like this.

The Exchequer needs to get rid of two carts of wooden tally sticks - remnants of an old accounting system.

When given the job, the Clerk of Works decides to burn these in underfloor stoves beneath the @ukhouseoflords. https://t.co/iPY1ZYyN0T

Today, 150 years on, the Palace of Westminster stands proud - a UNESCO World Heritage Site, a Grade I listed building, home to the biggest clock in the UK and the heart of British democracy.

See more about the last 150 years of the Palace of Westminster: https://t.co/sxAkV9HmrQ https://t.co/abN3FzOmFY

At the end of Pugin's life, Barry paid him a visit, where the younger architect supplied him with a detailed design for the iconic clock tower - now known as the Elizabeth Tower, or Big Ben - his final piece of work.

Long working hours and stress took its toll, and Charles Barry died 10 years before the completion of the Palace, leaving his son to take over.

Pugin's health also suffered from the exertions of rebuilding the Palace, and he was committed to Bedlam asylum before dying in 1852.

To this day, there's a lot of controversy over which architect deserves greater credit for the architectural triumph that is the Palace of Westminster.

But credit aside, neither Barry nor Pugin actually got to see the finished creation.

But there's another name very strongly associated with the building of the Palace of Westminster - Augustus Pugin. 

Barry turned to Pugin, a gifted young architect, to help him carry out the Gothic vision of the Palace.

The Palace was ruined. It needed rebuilding - so in 1836, there was a public competition to redesign the Palace of Westminster. The winner was Charles Barry, a Westminster-born architect.

Construction started in 1840, and in 1870 the Palace was completed - 150 years ago.

The morning of 16 October 1834, two workmen arrived at the Palace of Westminster. They'd been ordered to burn two cartloads of wooden sticks in stoves in the @UKHouseofLords basement.

By 6pm, a great fire had swept through the Palace, destroying both of the Houses of Parliament.

This year marks 150 years of the Palace of Westminster as we know it today - but there's a lot you might not know about this magnificent building.

This is the secret history of by who, how and why the Palace was rebuilt 150 years ago â¬‡ï¸ #Westminster150 https://t.co/GVLmfl9kSm

Can I start a petition? ğŸ™‹ğŸ½â€â™‚ï¸

Any British citizen or UK resident can start a petition. 

If you use the Parliament Petitions site and get over 10,000 signatures, the Government will respond. 

If it gets 100,000, it will be considered for Parliament debate.

https://t.co/QLYYadul72

Can I contact a member of the @UKHouseofLords? ğŸ™‹ğŸ¿â€â™€ï¸

You can contact a member of the House of Lords by issue or in relation to a draft law that affects you. 

Members of the Lords usually work on topics of particular policy interest or expertise.

https://t.co/zKgR9Mvmqs

Can I talk in person with my MP? ğŸ™‹

Most MPs hold regular sessions called surgeries where they meet constituents to talk about issues.

Itâ€™s best to contact your MPâ€™s office to find out whether you need an appointment or whether virtual surgeries are happening at the moment.

How can I found out who my MP is? ğŸ™‹â€â™‚ï¸

Just enter your postcode on our Find Your MP web page. 

You can write to, call, or email your MP.

https://t.co/1nzgaJtayu

How can my MP help on campaigns? ğŸ™‹

You can contact your MP to ask them to support a campaign that you feel strongly about.

If they agree to support this cause, they may also choose to raise it publicly in the @HouseofCommons through questions, debates, motions or amendments. https://t.co/zwpmhIvl6f

Parliament Buildings is open to the public Monday to Friday, 9am to 4pm. Free guided tours run at 11am and 2pm.

Parliament Buildings is much older than the Assembly: it opened in 1932. 

The building is 365 feet wide to match the number of days of the year. It has six floors, and there are six pillars at the entrance, one for each county of Northern Ireland. https://t.co/3V8d1uLfHZ

MLAs are elected using a form of proportional representation. If you're a registered voter in Northern Ireland, you'll vote by numbering the candidates in order of preference. Each MLA represents her or his constituency, and there are five MLAs for each constituency. https://t.co/4vyLn0fAd5

The @NIAssembly is the devolved assembly for Northern Ireland, and is home to 90 Members of the Legislative Assembly (MLAs). 

The Assembly was established after the Belfast Agreement 1998, also known as the Good Friday Agreement, and the first election was held that year. https://t.co/Agb04EFjOn

Do you recognise this UK landmark?

You can find out more about Nancy Astor on our website:

https://t.co/ykdlQqCeEr 

#Astor100 #OTD

As the first speech by a woman MP in the House of Commons, the speech was a milestone for political representation in the UK. 

However, Astor's legacy is complex and must be seen in the context of her later views.

In this maiden speech, Astor called for First World War restrictions on alcohol to continue. 

Her interest in temperance led to becoming the first woman MP to have a private member's bill passed into law. 

The bill introduced the UK age limit on sales of alcohol to under-18s. https://t.co/CIQ0HDsiix

"I know what I am talking about, and you must remember that women have got a vote now and we mean to use it."

On this day 100 years ago, Nancy Astor's first speech was the first time a woman spoke as an MP in the @HouseofCommons. https://t.co/oeqK5XcAEH

The Chamber / Siambr is set up in concentric rings with space for all 60 AMs.

It's designed to allow Members to see one other and make the democratic process more open and less confrontational.

There are 60 Assembly Members (AMs) elected every five years. 

If you're registered to vote in Wales, you vote for an AM in your local constituency: the candidate with most votes wins. 

You also vote for a party in a larger region using a form of proportional representation. https://t.co/UHPdX9oKN2

The National Assembly represents the interests of Wales and its people, makes laws for Wales, agrees Welsh taxes, and holds the Welsh Government to account.

Polari's use was at its height in the 1950s and '60s, when the Wolfenden Report was published. The language acted as both a disguise and an identification for gay men in public.

See the detail in Dolan's 'Wolfenden' below. #LGBTHistoryMonth https://t.co/m9RXqJsiQG

The Wolfenden Report was a landmark report produced in 1957 by a Committee set up to consider homosexual offences and prostitution.

It recommended that â€˜homosexual behavior between consenting adults in private be no longer a criminal offenceâ€™. https://t.co/nYg0kpErdF

Polari is a secretive slang known as 'the lost language of gay men'. 

In 2015, artist Jez Dolan used it to create a piece responding to the Wolfenden Report, translating parts of its recommendations into Polari. Find out why: https://t.co/3hzz0GiVco #LGBTHistoryMonth

1918 was an important step, but it was another ten years before men and women's voting rights were equal. 

The Representation of the People (Equal Franchise) Act 1928 meant women achieved the same voting rights as men. https://t.co/SVbclVMdLg

The first general election where women could vote and stand as MPs was in December 1918.

The @UKParlArchives holds this report showing how women were voting on the day. 

They also hold the election card of Mrs Bettie Le Cras, the first woman to vote at her polling station. https://t.co/7I86T3PmIL

On this day Parliament passed the first law allowing some women to vote: the Representation of the People Act 1918.

To vote, women had to be over 30 and own land or premises above a certain value, or be married to a man who did.

The Act also allowed all men over 21 to vote. https://t.co/maw6HXrjkN

The original Act is held in the @UKParlArchives. Find more on the Bill of Rights on our website: https://t.co/SNBKtNp8IE https://t.co/ixT7q4GchE

The Act established many fundamental legal protections. It made clear that the monarch could not change the law without Parliament's agreement. It also set out what's known as 'parliamentary privilege', meaning members of both Houses can speak freely without fear of legal action.

On this day in 1689 the Bill of Rights was given Royal Assent, the monarch's formal agreement to a law passed by both Houses of Parliament. The Act is still in force in England and Wales. #OTD https://t.co/49Rlu4i5m3

@Steve_Bromley Hi Steve, great question! There have been official election artists for each UK general election since 2001. In 2017, it was Cornelia Parker - we'll be highlighting her work this Thursday!

What's happening with this year's election artist? 

Nicky Hirst is the 2019 election artist. She's out on the campaign trail now, and will produce artwork in response to the 2019 election in 2020.  

You can follow Nicky's travels on Instagram: https://t.co/tg5EEcMSiS

The â€˜stableâ€™ in the title is a fictional space which allows for a collective visual of the General Election 2015 ğŸ–¼ï¸ 

See all the detail in the artwork: https://t.co/RD8DfWQTDI https://t.co/72KUtmbSqj

During the election, Adam Dant travelled the UK, filling over 24 sketchbooks with quick sketches and visual notes âœï¸

He used these to create 'The Government Stable', a visual narrative of the campaign in the run up to polling day ğŸ—³ï¸

What happened in 2015? 

Adam Dant was the 2015 election artist. He's known for large narrative ink drawings which approach British culture, politics and ideology in a satirical way. âœ’ï¸

The artist travels across the UK, observing the election campaign on the ground. They'll often work as they go, whether that's sketching, photographing or making notes on what they see and experience.

They produce a final artwork after polling day in response to the campaign. ğŸ–¼ï¸

What is an election artist? 

General elections are vital moments in the political history of the nation, and have been the subject of paintings and engravings since the 18th century. ğŸ“œ

There has been an official election artist for each UK general election since 2001.
As we gear up for the #GE2019, we're admiring some of the fantastic works of art produced by our previous election artists. ğŸ¨ğŸ–Œï¸

Our short film, produced by @RoyalHolloway along with the @UKParlArchives and @Citizens800, tells the story of Nancy Astor, the first woman to take her seat in the House of Commons.

#Astor100 https://t.co/uHG4wNWia8

Since 1918, 484 women have been elected to the House of Commons. 

After the 2017 General Election, the House of Commons included 211 women, 32% of all MPs. This was an all-time high.

Did you know: Nancy Astor was the first woman to take her seat, but the first woman to be elected to the Commons was Constance Markievicz. 

Elected in December 1918, as a member of Sinn FÃ©in she did not take her seat in the UK Parliament.

She spent almost two years as the only woman in the House of Commons. 

Many MPs refused to speak to her. Churchill later told her â€œwe hoped to freeze you outâ€.  

By 1931, she had been joined by more women MPs. https://t.co/FxsEnQ2Hii

Astor represented Plymouth Sutton from 1919 to 1945. 

Her welcome from the male MPs was not warm: "Sometimes I used to doubt whether it was a privilege. When I stood up and asked questions ... I used to be shouted at for five or ten minutes at a time."

100 years ago today, British politics changed forever. 

Nancy Astor became the first woman to sit in the @HouseofCommons on 1 December 1919, just one year after women became eligible to be MPs. 

#Astor100 https://t.co/CNeFeNDARs

The last witchcraft trials were held in Leicester in 1717, but in 1736 the Witchcraft Act was repealed and replaced with fines or imprisonment for people with magical powers. Its promoter was John Conduit, whose wife was the niece of Sir Isaac Newton.ğŸ”­ğŸ§™â€â™€ï¸

A further law banning witchcraft was passed in 1604. The 1562 and 1604 Acts transferred the trial of witches from the Church to the ordinary courts.

Overall, some 500 people in England are believed to have been executed for witchcraft. #Halloween2019

@britishlibrary During the 16th century, many people believed that witchcraft offered a more convincing explanation of sudden and unexpected ill-fortune.

The @HouseofCommons has only sat on four Saturdays since 1939 â€“ for the outbreak of World War 2, to finalise business before summer recess in 1949, for the Suez Crisis in 1956 and when the Falkland Islands were invaded in 1982.

@HouseofCommons Equianoâ€™s story and work had a profound impact on public attitudes towards slavery and the slave trade in 18th century Britain, which contributed to the later passing of the Slave Trade Act 1807 and the Slavery Abolition Act 1833.

@HouseofCommons â€œThe abolition of slavery would be in reality an universal good. Tortures, murder, and every other imaginable barbarity and iniquity, are practiced upon the poor slaves with impunity. I hope the slave-trade will be abolished.â€ âˆ’ Olaudah Equiano, 1789

Equiano attended debates in the @HouseofCommons on the abolition of the slave trade and wrote to parliamentarians and the government on the matter.

It's answer two: 1859.

Big Ben rang out on 11 July 1859 but its success was short-lived. In September 1859, the new bell also cracked and Big Ben was silent for four years. During this time, the hour was struck on the fourth quarter bell. https://t.co/cKSks6zqEL
When did Big Ben first chime?

It's answer three: 24,000 elements of scaffolding.

The illuminated coloured glass disks change over time and the sequence is linked to the tidal River Thames running past the Houses of Parliament.

Â© Parliamentary Art Collection, UK Parliament/Jessica Taylor https://t.co/jHwJJr3OXr

Of all the sculptural works in Parliament â€˜New Dawnâ€™ is my personal favourite. 

Itâ€™s a contemporary sculpture by Mary Branson made from metal and illuminated glass, and it commemorates the long campaign that led to some women gaining the vote in 1918, and all women in 1928.
ğŸ’¬ Whatâ€™s your favourite sculpture or statue in the collection? â“

Sir Edward John Poynter created the mosaics of St George and St David, and St Andrew at St Patrick were made by Robert Anning Bell. 

Saint George WOA 4257; Saint David WOA 4255; Saint Andrew WOA 4256; Saint Patrick WOA 4254. Â© Parliamentary Art Collection https://t.co/ftVtMc3V4U

Itâ€™s hard to pick just one! I think Iâ€™d have to choose the set of four mosaics in Central Lobby which show the four patron saints of England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland.

Theyâ€™re high up so visitors might not see them when they first enter the Lobby, but they are beautiful!
ğŸ’¬ What is your favourite object in the Parliamentary Art Collection? â“

By changing the viewing angle, you can flip between the different portraits â€“ this one shows portraits of Benjamin Disraeli, Lord Salisbury and Sir Stafford Northcote.

Image credit: Portrait of Disraeli, Salisbury and Stafford Northcote, WOA 6297 Â© Parliamentary Art Collection https://t.co/6Ez2rwic0v

I think one of the strangest is an optical illusion portrait which shows 3 different portraits, depending on which angle you view it from.

Itâ€™s formed of three prints, two of which have been glued back to back and cut into strips and fixed vertically in front of the other.
ğŸ’¬ What is the strangest object in the Parliamentary Art Collection? â“

They were once brightly coloured with rich paintwork and gilding, but this has worn away over the years to reveal the stone carving beneath. 

At over 600 years old, they are by far the oldest artworks in the collection! ğŸ‘‘

The oldest objects in the collection are the statues of medieval kings. These were commissioned by King Richard II in 1385 as part of his remodelling of Westminster Hall (originally completed by King William II in 1099).

Copyright: UK Parliament https://t.co/cRsVducwDq
ğŸ’¬ What is the oldest object in the Parliamentary Art Collection?â“

Our collections provide a unique perspective on the events that have shaped modern Britain.

UK Parliament holds important historic collections that have built up over centuries. We have a duty of care for these objects and our professionals ensure they are preserved for future generations. The first curator was appointed in 1853, and there have been curators ever since.

Where does the Queen come into this? ğŸ‘‘

The Queen is the only one who can prorogue Parliament, but she only does this on the advice of the Prime Minister.

Is it unusual to prorogue Parliament? 

No - Parliament is prorogued at the end of each session, which is usually about a year. However, the current session has lasted over two years. This is the longest for over 350 years: https://t.co/4jBOnSBRCZ

Why are people talking about prorogation?

The Queen has approved the Prime Ministerâ€™s request to suspend (prorogue) Parliament from the 10th September, days after MPs return from the summer recess.

In 1819 Manchester did not have its own Member of Parliament.

Now in 2019 Greater Manchester is represented by 27 MPs.

One of them is @LucyMPowell 

She tells us what Peterloo means to her. 

#Peterloo2019 https://t.co/lHJdVYZ5zh

Peterloo was a major event in Manchesterâ€™s history and a defining moment for Britainâ€™s democracy.

It was a catalyst for subsequent generations campaigning for change.

Manchester MP @LucyMPowell on why we should remember Peterloo.

#Peterloo2019 https://t.co/8USjMPnT0A

In 1819 around 2% of the population could vote. 

On 16 August 1819 60,000 people gathered in Manchester to demand representation. 

The massacre of these peaceful protesters became known as Peterloo.

Manchester MP @LucyMPowell explains what happened.

#Peterloo2019 https://t.co/IyLovgZdgg

Today we remember the 60,000 people who gathered in Manchester on 16 August 1819 to demand the vote and representation in Parliament.

18 of these peaceful protesters were killed and hundreds were injured but our democracy is their legacy.

#Peterloo2019 https://t.co/b9prbjDa9V

"Pride is one of those rare occasions when communities across the country and the world join together in one voice to celebrate our diversity and humanity, and to stand against the prejudice and violence that still exists."

"This is my first time marching in any Pride Parade. I wanted to march because it does look like incredibly good fun and also because after hiding who I was for so long I am sure I will get a sense of release to be visible and proud of myself."

"I do Pride, although much outside my comfort zone, to celebrate how far weâ€™ve come and to promote the continuation of social acceptance for future generations. Pride's important to me because I am fighting for equality in our community and for UK Parliament."
@ItsEmmaSte

"I think itâ€™s important that UK Parliament is seen participating at Pride. Not just for our staff but for the wider community and to set an example to other Parliaments."
@Piker_79

"After hiding my sexuality at work for more than a decade, since joining @UKParliament itâ€™s important to me to shout out loud and proud that I am a bi woman working here, in the hopes that others see that itâ€™s an open, friendly place to be themselves."
@Forestwytch

"Pride is important to me as an ally as I can show my support for the LGBT+ community. Pride makes me think about the last year, what I have done to be an good ally and what I can take forward to continue to be the best ally I can be."
@Nerys_d

It was first published in 1844!

Its full title is â€œA treatise on the law, privileges, proceedings and usage of Parliamentâ€ but it is referred to as Erskine May after its original author Thomas Erskine May. #FreeErskineMay

Brexit has been a huge focus for UK Parliament over the last three years. Today, we're taking you behind the scenes to meet teams communicating Brexit activities in Parliament.

On this day in 2016, the UK held a referendum on its membership of the EU, with the majority of voters choosing to leave. 51.9% voted in favour of leaving the EU, and 48.1% voted in favour of remaining a member of the EU.

Two years later, on June 5 1975, Britain held its first referendum on whether the UK should stay or leave the European Community, asking the public â€œDo you think the UK should stay in the European Community?â€ 67.2% voted in favour of staying.
The United Kingdom joined the European Economic Community on 1 January 1973 with Denmark and Ireland. Here is the original Act from @UKParlArchives. https://t.co/8A6dr2LKMr

This is the Form and Order of the Coronation of 1953 service. It tells us what those watching the Coronation were expected to do such as 'cry out with one voice GOD SAVE QUEEN ELIZABETH'. Want to know more about the history of women in Parliament? Watch this exclusive tour of 'Voice and Vote: Women's Place in Parliament' exhibition on Facebook
https://t.co/QVlYKcrTlZ

Sylvia wrote "In the potteries, I also saw the subordination of women workers. A woman was turning the wheel for the thrower, a woman was treading the lathe for the turner: each was employed by the man she toiled for â€“ the slave of a slave, I thought!".

In 1907, Sylvia Pankhurst toured northern England and Scotland to document the lives of women workers. Living in the communities she studied, she explored the rights of working women. Here are two pieces from the Parliamentary Art Collection. https://t.co/hW5v5nz7N6

Designed by Sylvia, this brooch was awarded to WSPU members who had been imprisoned. The design is the Portcullis symbol of the @HouseofCommons with a silver gate and hanging chains, and the superimposed broad arrow (the conflict symbol) in purple, white and green enamel. https://t.co/FNghKBlARm

Sylvia Pankhurst was born in 1882, it was not until 1918 that UK Parliament passed a law allowing some women, and all men, to vote for the first time: the 1918 Representation of the People Act. https://t.co/5HxsMKFflC

On 25 April 1906, suffragettes held a protest in Parliament. Leaders of the WSPU, including Sylvia, were 'sitting in the front row with their faces tightly pressed to the hated grille' they beat their hands against it, crying 'votes for women'. https://t.co/yDqyrUcTls

On this day in 1882, suffragette Sylvia Pankhurst was born. She had a profound impact on the fight for womenâ€™s rights as both a campaigner and an artist. She was a member of the Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU) alongside her mother and sisters. 

Read on to learn more. https://t.co/AOocq3znsv

We stand ready to learn any lessons that emerge from the fire at Notre Dame to ensure we do everything possible to protect our community, our visitors, and our buildings. (4/5)
Works include fire door upgrades, fire safety signage, and a high-pressure water mist system. We also have teams of fire safety officers patrolling the Palace 24 hours a day to spot any issues. (3/5)
Fire safety is something we take really seriously. Last year, we completed a significant proportion of improvement works to enhance fire safety measures in the Palace. (2/5)

Following the devastating fire at the iconic Notre-Dame cathedral yesterday, people have asked what steps weâ€™re taking to protect the UNESCO World Heritage site and gothic-inspired architecture of the Palace of Westminster from the risk of fire. (1/5) https://t.co/GPh7VvcOkL

On this day in 1689 the Bill of Rights was given Royal Assent. Established frequent parliaments, free elections and freedom of speech in Parliament. Today this is known as Parliamentary Privilege. https://t.co/1BlF4WPjQi
@chrissyteigen Hi @chrissyteigen, lots of people have asked us this question. We've done our best to explain the significance of removing the mace in this thread here: https://t.co/NoWxUlzx7m

By 1700, it was accepted that the Mace had to be present. Even today, the Mace in Parliament is the symbol of royal authority and without it neither House can meet or pass laws. So when the Mace was removed in protest this week Parliamentary debate could not continue. https://t.co/0Opke869lX
The first written reference to 'the House of Commons Mace' is in 1614, but it is unclear as to why the House may be unable to function without it and the text itself seems to question it.

Maces are a development of clubs and staves â€“ used in combat for hundreds of years, and were weapons of the bodyguard of the Serjeant at Arms under the Plantagenets. No-one is sure of when the idea first appeared that without the Mace the @HouseofCommons could not function.

Often referred to as 'the House of Commons Mace', it is actually a Royal Mace from the @RCT. The Charles II Mace now in use was not designed for the Commons but seems to have been assigned to the @HouseofCommons since the beginning of the 19th Century. https://t.co/thRoBzlsyj

This week a mace in the @HouseofCommons was in the spotlight when an MP removed it in protest during a debate. Many of you asked us about its significance. Read on to learn more. https://t.co/IUzE5OisYe

This week MPs placed letters in a time capsule about their hopes for an equal society in the future. This will be opened in 2028, to mark 100 years since equal voting rights for men and women were finally achieved. #Vote100 

Â© UK Parliament/Jessica Taylor https://t.co/jEgL1EUfNd

Did women turn out to vote in 1918? 

Below is a report from @UKParlArchives showing how women were voting in different regions on the day, the second image is the election card of Mrs Bettie Le Cras, she was the first woman to vote at her polling station. #Vote100 https://t.co/PZndIKM8Nd

The first woman to be elected to the @HouseofCommons was Constance Markievicz. But she did not take her seat. One year later Nancy Astor became the first woman to take her seat in Parliament. This @BritishPathe footage shows her on polling day in 1919. https://t.co/brXb9xqjgg

Earlier this morning we asked you how many female MPs stood for election in 1918? The answer is 17.

Only one of the 707 Members elected in 1918 was a woman, compared to 208 out of 650 MPs in 2017. Her name was Constance Markievicz. #Vote100
How many female MPs stood for election in December 1918?

100 years ago today a general election was held that represented a shift in British politics - women could be elected as MPs for the first time. It was also the first general election where some women and all men over 21 could vote. Equal voting rights wouldn't be won until 1928 https://t.co/tEE41J84zY

Baroness Trumpington was an active and popular member of the House of Lords Works of Art Committee. This portrait photograph by @desireep shows her sitting the former Lord Chancellor's residence in the @UKHouseofLords.  Â© Parliamentary Art Collection https://t.co/cqTtpthPhM

Baroness Trumpington was regarded as a vocal and respected figure in the @conservatives government. Amongst her ministerial roles, she also served as the Baroness-in-waiting to the Queen @RoyalFamily.

On 4 February 1980, she was created a life peer in @UKHouseofLords, choosing the title Baroness Trumpington. Before entering Parliament, she served as a councillor in Cambridge and was the city's mayor in 1971-72.

During the Second World War, Lady Trumpington - who was fluent in French, German and Italian â€“ used her impressive language skills as a cypher clerk for naval intelligence at the famous @BletchleyPark.

#BaronessTrumpington has died at the age of 96, and today we're marking her life and contribution to Parliament. She shot to fame in 2011 for a particular event in the @UKHouseofLords, but what was she truly known for? Read on to find out â¬‡ï¸

Here are 5 things you probably didn't know about the Gunpowder Plot.

#GuyFawkesNight https://t.co/F5sHhqajvi

In 1606, Parliament passed the Thanksgiving Act calling for an annual thanksgiving for the failure of the plot.

Parliament is still searched by the Yeomen of the Guard before the State Opening of Parliament to ensure no latter-day Guy Fawkes is hiding in the cellars. #GuyFawkes https://t.co/1FOVbI8hVo

36 barrels of gunpowder were found under a pile of firewood. Fawkes was taken to King James I on the morning of the 5 November and then sent to @TowerofLondon for interrogation. After days of torture, Fawkes eventually began to name the other conspirators. 

#GuyFawkes https://t.co/ZIr39SCamE

Remember, remember...the 4th of November?

Guy Fawkes was actually discovered on the night of 4 November, during a search of the cellars under Parliament. He was carrying a lantern, a pocket watch and matches. 

#GuyFawkes https://t.co/aEDtaEMlNg

The last witchcraft trials were held in Leicester in 1717, but in 1736 the Witchcraft Act was replaced with fines or imprisonment for people with magical powers, much to the amusement of MPs. Its promoter was John Conduit, whose wife was the niece of Sir Isaac Newton.

A further law banning witchcraft was passed in 1604. The 1562 and 1604 Acts transferred the trial of witches from the Church to the ordinary courts. 

Overall, some 500 people in England are believed to have been executed for witchcraft. 

#Halloween https://t.co/sLPU0oXiJW

During the 16th century, many people believed that witchcraft offered a more convincing explanation of sudden and unexpected ill-fortune. In 1542, Parliament passed the Witchcraft Act which defined witchcraft as a crime punishable by death. 

#Halloween https://t.co/rO7xlDdFjV

Answer: it was King James I who took a keen interest in demonology. He published a compendium on witchcraft lore called 'Daemonologie' in 1597.

The @britishlibrary hold a copy in their collection which you can read about here: https://t.co/L5DETRjaw4
#Halloween

In 1834 Parliament was destroyed by fire, and as part of the rebuild by Charles Barry, a dedicated gallery for women was created, it was nicknamed 'The Cage' due to the grilles over the windows. This is where the famous protest took place. #Vote100

Â© Parliamentary Archives https://t.co/98uwKzPHLq

In the early 19th century, women had no access to the @HouseofCommons , meaning they could not watch or listen to parliamentary debates. Before 1834, well-connected women watched proceedings through a ventilation shaft in the ceiling.

Â© Parliamentary Art Collection #Vote100 https://t.co/MA70UV7wjc

#OTD in 1908 the most famous protest in the Ladies' Gallery took place, where women chained themselves to the grille shouting, 'We have been behind this insulting grille too long!' whilst thrusting a banner, pictured below, through the grille down into the chamber. #Vote100 https://t.co/0XstmTnmBX
